summary: This is a letter from the Federal Bureau of Prisons at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn to Judge Alison J. Nathan, responding to her order regarding an alleged incident involving Ghislaine Maxwell on April 24, 2021. The letter clarifies that no materials were seized from Maxwell during a legal visit, that confiscated items were returned to defense counsel, and outlines procedures to ensure attorney-client confidentiality.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell

events.title: Alleged Incident at MDC Brooklyn Legal Visit
events.description: An incident occurred during Ghislaine Maxwell's legal visit at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn, prompting a judicial inquiry. Materials given to Maxwell by defense counsel contrary to procedures were confiscated but later returned.

events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issued an order seeking information about the April 24, 2021 incident involving Ghislaine Maxwell at MDC Brooklyn, including details about seized materials and attorney-client confidentiality safeguards.

events.description: Materials confiscated from Ghislaine Maxwell during the April 24 legal visit were returned to her defense counsel.

keyFacts: No materials were seized from Ghislaine Maxwell during or after her April 24, 2021 legal visit at MDC Brooklyn; confiscated items were returned to defense counsel the next day.
None of Maxwell's legal materials, including those from the April 24 visit, were photocopied by MDC Brooklyn staff.
MDC Brooklyn procedures allow inmates to bring legal materials to in-person meetings with counsel, subject to visual inspection for contraband, and legal visits are visually monitored only.
Ghislaine Maxwell can meet with defense counsel via video-teleconference for up to five hours per day, Monday through Friday, in a private room with visual supervision.
The letter is a formal response to Judge Alison J. Nathan's order, affirming compliance with procedures to ensure attorney-client communications remain confidential.
